required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Patient Satisfaction and Safety With Propofol Based Sedation With or Without Fentanyl for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy
clinical_study.official_title: Patient Satisfaction and Safety With Propofol Based Sedation With or Without Fentanyl for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy :a Prospective ,Randomized ,and Cohort Study

brief_summary.textblock: Patient satisfaction and safety with propofol based sedation with or without fentanyl for gastrointestinal endoscopy

detailed_description.textblock: This study divide patients into two groups, one will be given propofol midazolam and fentanyl; another group was given propofol with midazolam without fentanyl; to observe two groups of patients blood pressure, body movement, and propofol dosage , and the difference in operator satisfaction, and how many people need to give fentanyl again; and two groups of patients after the operation of the reaction, if there are dizziness, nausea, and other adverse reactions; finally, the differences of these two schemes in different populations were analyzed, and the rationalization and individualized medication will be put forward.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants are randomly assigned to group A or B. Participants of group A are given propofol midazolam and fentanyl; while participants of group B are given propofol with midazolam without fentany

primary_outcome.measure: Satisfaction assessed by the rate of vomit and diazzy after the procedure
primary_outcome.description: Rates of vomit and diazzy of patients after the procedure between the two groups

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety assessed by the rate of hypoxia during the procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Hypoxia, defined as peripheral oxygen saturation <90% for >30 seconds

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety assessed by the rate of hypotention during the procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Hypotension, defined as systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety assessed by the rate of hyoxemia during the procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Hypoxia, defined as peripheral oxygen saturation <90% for >30 seconds

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety assessed by the rate of breadycardia during the procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Bradycardia, defined as heart rate <50 beats/min

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety assessed by the rate of required airway management during the procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Required airway management such as jaw lifting, mask ventilation, or tracheal intubation in severe hypoxia

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety assessed by the rate of involuntary movement during the procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Involuntary movements, defined as unconscious movements requiring restraint or severe limb movement interrupting the endoscopy procedure

arm_group.description: Participants are given standard regimen: 50-200mg propofol and 1 mg midazolam
Participants are given intervention regimen: 50ug fentanyl, plus 50-200mg propofol and 1 mg midazolam.

intervention.description: participants in both groups are given standard regimen including 50-200mg propofol.
participants in fentanyl group are given intervention regimen: 50ug fentanyl.
participants in both groups are given standard regimen including 1 mg midazolam.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged 18 or older
- Patients scheduled for an outpatient gastrointestinal endoscopy by the principal investigator.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with a history of colorectal surgery
- Patients with ASA class 4 or 5,
- Patients with pre-existing hypoxaemia (SpO2<90%),
- Patients with hypotension (SBP<90mmHg)
- Patients with bradycardia (HR<50 bpm)
- patients with severe chronic renal failure (creatinine clearance<30 ml/min)
- patients with uncontrolled hypertension (systolic blood pressure>170 mm Hg, diastolic blood pressure>100 mm Hg)
- patients with pregnancy or lactation
- Patients hemodynamically unstable
- Patients unable to give informed consent
- Patients with a history of drug allergies;
